subject: Re: What happened to o?
msgSnippet: The dictionary has been generated with the CMU phonetic dictionary, wich is based on American pronunciation. In this pronunciation, y and o are considered one
messageBody:
The dictionary has been generated with the CMU phonetic dictionary,
wich is based on American pronunciation. In this pronunciation, y and
o are considered one sound.

I know of no British-English pronunciation dictionary. If anyone
knows, please tell!

Ewout Stam
/EvQt stym

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Frederick C Tarbox III"
<rtarbox@d...> wrote:
> So, in the dictionary that's posted on this group, I did a search
for the (jerome.ttf) letter "o", and found *nothing*. Even the guide
words Ox and On are spelled "yks" and "yn".
>
> Since I never Received my Pronunciation, I am at a lost as to how
to pronounce "o", since I myself pronounce Ox and On differently.
>
> Anyone here want to help me out?
>
> I think I have it, from all the examples in the manual, but I keep
getting confused with the nearby vowels "y" and "Y".
>
> Anyways, stealing a word from "Ride a-cock Horse," I've come up
with a mnemonic for four of the vowels:
>
> a cross
> exam
>
> a kros
> egzAm
>
> Write it out in Quikscript and the four vowels form the four
quarters of a circle.
>
> And for the diphthongs:
> cowboy's
> gravesite
>
> (There are in fact a lot of words for E+F, but finding a Q+q word
leaves me with Cowboy and Mountjoy...)

The dictionary has been generated with the CMU phonetic dictionary, 
wich is based on American pronunciation. In this pronunciation, y and 
o are considered one sound.

I know of no British-English pronunciation dictionary. If anyone 
knows, please tell!

Ewout Stam
/EvQt stym
